1458857860406861825.text:
None of us have it all figured out. I don’t care how smart you think you are or what position you hold -- listen to the wisdom of others. 

Be thankful that the worst-case scenario can be avoided by listening to someone wiser than you.

1458857859043704838.text:
That Lance Corporal is alive today because my Battalion Commander made a good decision.

And Second Lieutenant Auchincloss thought that he was wiser.

I think about that often. I try to embed that humility into how I approach questions big and small.

1458857857856770050.text:
Then it came through from my Platoon Sergeant who had been in the lead vehicle -- no casualties. 

And second only to the birth of my children, it was the best feeling in the world.

1458857856619454471.text:
I may have thought we sacrificed training, but my Marines showed me otherwise.

I didn’t even have to give an order. They were sweeping. They were providing cover. They were evacuating the Marines.

And there were about 45 seconds of radio silence.

1458857855130419205.text: I’ll never forget that feeling; I can see it in my consciousness now. I could picture the driver of the lead vehicle. Lance Corporal. 19 years old. It was like every drop of blood was out of my body.

1458857853171777546.text:
Immediately, I thought something wasn’t right. This is exactly what the Taliban wanted us to be doing. We needed to rethink this. 

BOOM! An IED struck our lead vehicle.

1458857851925975042.text:
I commanded a forward patrol base. We were going out on daily patrols of Taliban-influenced villages. One day, there was a gunfight down at Helmand River and we were the closest platoon. 

I directed the platoon in single file down a narrow dirt road to the village.

1458857850474835976.text:
23-year-old Second Lieutenant Auchincloss thought that this Lieutenant Colonel did not know what he was doing. I thought it was going to hinder our offensive capabilities and really undermine our training. 

I believed this decision was a mistake.

1458857849279422476.text:
Right before we left, our Battalion Commander made a decision that we were going to switch out the vehicles that we were using, from light armored vehicles to IED resistant vehicles.

This came at a cost. It hindered our mobility, maintenance, and firepower.

1458857848012738568.text:
I graduated infantry in 2011 at 23 years old. Boy, was I confident. 

I knew the tactics. I did well in training. And upon deployment to Afghanistan, I thought I had it figured out.

1458857846418857986.text:
On Veterans Day, I wanted to share a story with you about my own service. It’s a story of humility, and one of the most important lessons that I’ve learned. 

Thread 👇 https://t.co/yIxDvAEcAz

1362530576448782336.text: Gamifying day-trading, payment for order flow, and encouraging options trading prevent Robinhood from being a fiduciary to its customers, as required by Massachusetts law. Robinhood needs to make changes to protect its’ customers best interests.

1362530575467352068.text:
Due to the complexity of options trading, new or casual investors are destined to lose out to experienced options traders.
 
68% of MA customers approved for options trading on @RobinhoodApp had limited to no investment experience.

1362530574565531655.text: Options are a complicated investment tool. Yes, they are a fast way to make money. They are also a fast way to lose money. Industry regulators require brokerages to vet customers who want to trade options. Robinhood, by contrast, pushes options onto its users.

1362530573441523716.text:
Payment for order flow is Robinhood’s primary source of revenue and the reason it can offer commission-free trading to customers.
 
Doesn’t payment for order flow incentivize Robinhood to encourage customers to trade as often as possible regardless of their trade quality?

1362530572493598720.text: Robinhood must explain how it can claim to comply with Massachusetts’ best-interest rule when it clearly incentivizes everyday people to become day traders.

1362530571033919491.text: The vast majority of retail day traders, who try to pick individual stocks in competition with professional traders, lose money – and only about 1% consistently get better returns than low-cost index funds.

1362530570027343873.text: Right now, half of US households have no stocks at all. Democratizing access to assets is an important objective – we *want* Main Street to own more of Wall Street. However, the best way to do that is through low-cost index funds, mutual funds, or ETFs.
